author: {'steamid': '76561198028570547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2563, 'playtime_forever': 170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1522698830}
review:
"Mall Empire" ist ein kleines Management Spiel. Zumindest scheint es auf den ersten Blick so.

Als 1994 "SimTower" erschien, überraschte es mit erstaunlich unterhaltendem und interessantem Gameplay. Man baute nach und nach einen Wolkenkratzer aus, platzierte Geschäfte und Aufzüge und versuchte, die innere Ökonomie in Gang zu halten. Dabei war dieser Urvater detailverliebt und komplex, bis hin zu der Möglichkeit, jeden einzelnen Bewohner zu verfolgen.

"Mall Empire" versucht sich in der gleichen Kategorie und erreicht den Urvater in keinem einzigen Aspekt. Im Gegenteil, es ist simplifiziert bis zum Abwinken, nach kürzester Zeit stinklangweilig und ohne jede Komplexität oder taktische Tiefe.

Man baut lediglich Geschäfte, für die man Blaupausen freischalten muss oder Aufzüge. Letztere brauchen keinerlei Management. Die Kunden kommen im Haufen. Waren sie in einem Geschäft, zeigt das Spiel seinen eigentlichen Kern. Denn nun müssen wir in einem Zeitlimit auf das Geschäft und auf eine Schaltfläche klicken, um Einnahmen zu generieren. Zudem können wir Geschäfte im Laufe der Zeit aufrüsten. Man erhält immer fünf Punkte, muß also immer fünfmal Klicken, um eine Aufrüstungsstufe voll auszuschöpfen. 

Und das ist es eigentlich: ein Clicker-Spielchen mit ein wenig Gedöns drumrum. Die Einnahmen erhöhen und potenzieren sich rasch. Herausforderung kommt nie auf. Spaß sicher auch nicht.

Die schwache Grafik, die nervige Musik oder das oft schwerfällig reagierende Baumenü brauch ich da kaum noch ins Feld zu führen. 

[h1]Wertung:[/h1]
3/10 Atmosphäre
-/10 Story
3/10 Grafik
2/10 Sound
2/10 Spielmechanik
1/10 Balancing
2/10 Spielspass

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
Clicker-Spiel im Management-Mantel.

[h1][b]2/10 Gesamtwertung

But even if the game was bug-free it would still be shit as the gameplay is so plain, boring and downright annoying because of the neccessity to manually collect your profits. The game doesn't make sense, UI is abyssmal, bugs everywhere and on top of that I've seen developer with his "google translator english" calling "haters" the people who criticized his precious little game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964641301', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 312, 'playtime_forever': 265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 265, 'last_played': 1514272756}
review:
That game is a fine example of a great idea, which is unfortunately poorly executed. I mean, first it really looks like a promising game. You can get to unlock some stores, invest some money to improve your income, get a loan if you need etc. Then, when you click to unpause, you realize where you've just got yourself into...

Well, how could I describe it in a practical manner? I guess that the best way, it would be to call it a "micro-management fest". That's because you actually gotta click on every single store that you have every day, in order to collect the cash that you make. At the beginning, it's no big deal, but just wait a lil' while and you'll see what madness it is. Oh, and if one reason isn't more than enough, you also have to click often to upgrade your stores as they level up (increasing stock and quality of items). So, pick up these two chaotic ingredients, blend them up and now you have a cocktail from hell. Of course, we can't forget to put a cherry inside of it: This game is one of those notorious achievements spammers. That by itself isn't really a big issue, except that the developers should have never inserted the damn buttons that you have to click on all the time, precisely at the right corner of the screen.

Ok, what else... There're also some broken achievements. That's because there're some you can only unlock after building a certain combination of stores. No matter how many times you try, they simply won't work. This game should also be known as one of those "FPS killers", because depending on how big your mall is, things will become really sluggish, and that can definitely wear on your patience (kinda like adding insult to injury). Hmm, there're some glitches too. I've seen some customers walking on air for whatever reason; there were times where I couldn't build an elevator (at all), and there were also some stores that wouldn't fit where you've clicked (they'd always skip to the next block).

Now that we're through all this, then what about the overall aspects? The graphics are ok, I guess. My only complaint is that the stores seem dead, as there's no movement going on, other than the costumers walking in front of them. There're no sound effects, and there's only one song available, which isn't really a bad thing, but it naturally gets annoying after listening to it for a long period of time. The game doesn't provide you any campaign mode, so my only guess is that you can say that you've truly finished this game, after you've successfully managed to unlock every possible achievement. As mentioned earlier, the gameplay itself could really use some improvement.

Well, for now this is my opinion. I doubt that the gameplay mechanics of having to click all the time will ever change, but I think that at least the broken achievements could be fixed. Just to finish, I hope that the next games from that company will be better, because their premise is surely interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069634986', 'num_games_owned': 3362, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 377, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 293, 'last_played': 1504433436}
review:
[b]Mall Empire[/b] is a seemingly attractive indie strategy/management game which is entertaining for a while but is unfortunately full of flaws that don't let the game live up to its full potential.

Check out this review and many others on Save or Quit: http://saveorquit.com/2017/09/08/review-mall-empire/

This game tries to mimic similar successful titles, Project Highrise being just one example. Your goal is to get as much money as possible by building a shopping mall and evolving it as you get more customers and more money.

The concept is fun and the game looks like fun at first but soon enough, it becomes obvious that there are countless problems that ruin the whole experience. Let's start at the beginning. As soon as I started the game ... it crashed. "No problem," I said to myself. "this can happen sometimes." Sure enough, the game started normally next time. However, a few hours later I started browsing the community forum and it seems like this has been happening to a whole bunch of people. I tried starting the game multiple times and it still crashes about 20% of the time for some reason.

The tutorial is somehow helpful, but it is sadly filled with grammatical errors, typos, and other things. Here's an example: "If you will upgrade stock, then your store will can to sell more products." Luckily, the tutorial is more or less the only thing you will have to read in this game.

The graphics are overall quite good-looking. The main menu is beautiful, the stores and the environment are also okay. The animations don't quite hit the spot, though. People buy things like this: 1. walk to the store, 2. touch the store for a millisecond and 3. walk away immediately. You don't see people spending their time around the mall and shopping like they're supposed to. They just come and go and they're not particularly slow at doing that. Another animation issue is the lack of the day-turning-to-night-and-vice-versa transition animation. When the daytime "times out", the bright background instantly switches into the dark one.

Since I'm already talking about time, here's another thing I noticed. I'm sure you know that all similar management games have time control buttons which allow you to speed up the time to ensure you can waste your whole weekend more effectively. This game has that too, but that is not the problem. The problem is the pause button. When you pause it, the time stops - no surprise there. However, when you resume the game, the time doesn't start running normally, it just fast forwards to the time the game would reach had the pause button not been pressed. "But that's good," I hear you say, "at least the game got you plenty of money in the meantime and you don't have to take loans and stuff!" Well, no. You see, although you lose a lot of in-game time, your other stats don't actually change. In that time, no customers arrived and entrusted you with their hard-earned money.

There is another issue regarding time in this game, but it invokes giggles instead of rage. One in-game day lasts two minutes in real life and progresses the in-game clock by one week. For some reason. I don't understand what is the point of having the day and night cycle if you're not gonna stick by it.

The issues do not end here, sadly. I really can't understand why I have to collect money myself. Every once in a while, a certain store will inform you that it is now time to collect the money and that you have 30 seconds to do so. No other similar game does this and it's for a good reason: it's annoying and it's dumb. Also, as you get visited by your beloved customers, you earn the so-called "rating", which is a sort of customer satisfaction. You can then [i]spend[/i] the rating (goodbye, logic) to buy store blueprints.

This game also features a store upgrade system, which allows you to, you guessed it, upgrade your stores. This sounds good and it is, in fact, crucial if you want to succeed in this game. Why? Because without the upgrades, some stores have as little as [i]FIVE[/i] pieces of their product in stock. "Want to buy some bread, buddy? Well, that's bad luck, five people came before you already." Ridiculous. And that's not the only weird thing with Mall Empire's stock system. Even restrooms and parks are limited in how many people they can serve per day.

This weird system brings up a very interesting question: how on earth do you earn any money if you can only sell five loaves of bread per day? Here's the obvious solution: you raise its damn price. I had a nice long laugh after I noticed something when I upgraded the restrooms: a single usage of the toilet brought me [i]fifteen hundred dollars[/i]. Those better be some gold-plated toilets for that price.

The controls are no better, too. You can't zoom in or out, which can be a problem once your establishment consists of more than five floors. Moving the camera with your mouse for some reason also lags the customers (the FPS did not drop one bit, however) while the time counter ticks down seconds like usual, which in theory reduces your daily profits. When placing stores into your mall, you may also have issues with stores that take up more space. When I was trying to place the bar, I somehow placed it [i]over[/i] some of the existing infrastructures. This prevented me from collecting money from the covered up areas. I could destroy the bar in order to reveal the stores beneath, but I would lose $350k (this game does not refund your money when you destroy stores. Of course.).

Although this is not a full list of everything that is wrong with this game, I will only mention one other thing: the achievements. There are 400 of them and they were obviously integrated into the game to attract achievement hunters. Nothing wrong with that, we cannot argue the principle of supply and demand. However, the achievements are screwed up in a number of different ways. Firstly, you get the "build" achievement when you buy a blueprint for a store and the "buy a blueprint" achievement when you build a store. Furthermore, the achievements which you are supposed to get when you reach a certain amount of gained profit in a month work the same as the achievements for total earnings, but with one little difference: you get the achievement for total earnings 1-2 minutes [i]after[/i] the "in a month" achievement.

I do also want to say that I love the music in this game. It's funky.

There are a lot of things that make this game bad, but for some weird enough reason, I still played it for about two hours straight. I couldn't stop. Do I recommend it? Not really, no. This is the poor man's version of Project Highrise and I do mean poor man's. Both games go on sale quite often and if you feel like managing some buildings, you should only buy this game if you're a bit desperate and you're as broke as you'll ever be. I'm not saying you won't enjoy this game - for a few hours, you probably will. I did. But still, do yourself a favor and buy some other game with a decent level of quality.

With love,
BirdCute

author: {'steamid': '76561197970286594', 'num_games_owned': 1747, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1498003347}
review:
Saw this game available on Chrono.gg for $2.50 and saw that the reviews were mostly positive, so I decided to take a punt.
What a complete waste of $2.50.
There's really nothing here that resembles strategy or even gameplay, for the most part. You buy store blueprints with a "heart" currency, build new stores with money, sell products to gain money and hearts, rinse and repeat.
There doesn't seem to be anything more to it other than the relentless clicking. To collect money from the stores you have to click on the store (which has a 4x4 pixel icon on it if there's money to be collected), then click on a menu icon to collect its money. As stores sell goods they'll level up, get a 4x4 upgrade icon and then need to be clicked on and upgraded by clicking on the menu bar, putting 5 points into two mysterious stats using tiny, tiny buttons, then click the close button on the upgrade window, then click the close button on the next "You have successfully upgraded your store with these exact stats that appeared on the previous menu" window.
The whole experience is a miserable UI disaster that would be far more comfortable in a touch-based interface, but which would *still* be terrible even then. It would just be *less* terrible.
The developers seem to have abandoned the game back in April, and probably aren't coming back; I don't think there's anything worth saving/patching here anyway. Not without totally redesigning the game from the ground up. 

The soundtrack is pretty sweet though, I'll give them that much.

But yeah, the only reason to write this review is to try and counter the ridiculous number of positive reviews this game has. This is not a positive-review game. It's a terrible, terrible game, and you should not buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059578520', 'num_games_owned': 883, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 133, 'last_played': 1498500129}
review:
For $2.50 (where it's currently on Chrono.gg for) I'd certainly say it's worth it. I've only just started but I can already see a lot of potential. First, it's not a very in-depth game (at the moment, I can't say that that is what the indie developers final goal is by any means), so if it's depth you're looking for I think you might want to look elsewhere until the game gets further in development. That being said, it fits with the style of the game, that style being minimalistic. It's a very minimalistic game and I think that's great for a game of this Tycoon genre.
On the topic of development, the developers are keeping the fans updated which is important in this day and age where indie development isn't always trustworthy due to games like No Man's Sky. Being updated on the content that gets added fairly frequently is a great thing to hear from developers and regardless of how this game turns out I'd be glad to keep an eye on what these developers do in the future, because I can trust them.
Back on the topic of the game I think it's great for people just wanting to relax. I mentioned how it's not very in-depth at the moment, and that's because, from what I understand of the game, the stores you choose don't make much of a difference, I mean, even the rest areas cost the customers. That makes me feel that, as it is, so far, the game seems like it's more of a build your own dream mall, than an actual tycoon. I don't mind that at all in my opinion, but I'm also looking forward to any future changes the devs make. I still think it's almost certainly worth the $2.50 on Chrono.gg at the moment.
I also mentioned the minimalistic style of it. I've played many flash games and app games and enjoyed a great variety of similar ones, but they don't feel as good as this game does to play, unlike free flash and most app games, this game is polished. Unlike in app games, this game isn't pushing microtransactions like they normally do. The minimalistic style is a nice style for the game as it fits the simplistic mechanics of the game.
I might have only played 0.1 hours at the moment of making this review, but after being in the mood for some game I couldn't think of for the longest time, I found this game, and it was a simple enough game that I know I'll enjoy for a short time. And I know that there'll be more to come and that there's plenty of content that I haven't even scratched the surface of with how much I've played and I'm looking forward to discovering it all.

review:
TL:DR - Don't buy it, even on sale this is just a broken and boring clicker game which you HAVE to stare at to even let it run.
Many bugs (some game breaking) which are easy to come by and developers have still not fixed them since April. 


Will update my review when any progress/fixes have been done. But for now do not waste your money on this boring clicker game.

It has potential but it is failing to show itself.

----------------------------------------------

I have played games like this before, I loved them and was happy when I was gifted this because it looked like it would play like those games where you build a hotel and decide what goes where and such. But....this is a let down...

The game pauses when you click off the game so if you want it to run in the background, too bad you will not get any gain at all.
The pause button in-game does pause the game but soon as you press play again it speeds up how many days/nights you would of missed to begin with making it pointless as a pause button!

You have to click your shops to get the money and after a while this gets boring, specially when you have many shops and you NEED to scroll across the screen to check if a shop needs money collecting. You can scroll with arrow keys but it is PAINFULLY slow that I question why even have it there. The mouse scroll is much faster.


If you don't feel like collecting from your shops, there is an "auto-collect". Good, you can semi-afk while reading a book (though why you would use your computer just to run this boring game and not use it for more fun things is beyond me) HOWEVER. It only collects 50% of what you would of gotten if you collected it yourself.

You can rank up your store if certain parts are met, such as enough shops or customers. But this is where auto-collect is more of a death sentence. Some of the items you buy, such as advertising, is daily. Which means if you bought the 10k one, you lose 10k everyday. WHY! Why not just let it be a one time thing and let me re-buy it if I wanted more customers? why force the money out of our pockets over something that seems to be a one time thing like the other upgrades were? that is stupid and misleading as well. No where does it state it is daily, this is why my money kept being drained like hell and heck the increased customers did nothing of use for me anyway.


Lastly, some of the placeables do not work. When I want to make a new floor, it won't let me. So I place a hallway down which is 10x more. Still nothing.
If a hallway DOES place down it is only 1 room! while the floor which is marked at 10k (is actually 100k nice typo developers) fills the next entire row. So what the hell? Why have a floor and hallway if both do the same thing but one just makes 1 room, just get rid of it. While you are at it, bloody make sure it works. I don't want to be clicking 5 times just to hope it places an actual floor down. Heck on some save-files I could not place a new floor at all, so I had to start a new game and lose my progress, this has happened TWICE! Wonderful, thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032137848', 'num_games_owned': 1957, 'num_reviews': 775, 'playtime_forever': 1632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 416, 'last_played': 1509852033}
review:
Very cute little budget version of Projecct Highrise. Interestingly, this is NOT a mobile port, it was made for the PC. Unfortunately they added things that make it too "Appish" and hopefully, and per some of the Devs comments, will be removed or tweaked. These being the "Click" stuff. It's GOT to go for this to be a real success, which I think it should be. Having to click your stores individually to recieve all the money, or NOT click and only get half your earnings is not acceptable, as most buyers have already stated. It does require a little "hide and watch" the gameplay to get the hang of things but if you've got an IQ over 25 it won't take you long. Graphically, it is very cute and acceptable, already has a lot of stores and so forth, I like the "combination" feature where you can get extra bonuses for certain store combos (Once I figure out how to use it..lol).  For this price, even with no discount at all, it's a very playable and addictive little game for a break from some big FPS or TBS/RTS game.  

Cons would be, and so far only, the click stuff has to be refined, which they say they are going to do. Likewise a few translations are certainly "English is not your first language" obvious, nit-picky but must be corrected just for apperances/quality sake. We all see this often in little indie games and no big deal, but it does matter for apperances/quality.

Overall it's a very worthwhile purchase if you are into the "Sim tower" type genre, and it really does feel to me like a budget version of Project Hiighrise and has a great deal of potential if they keep tweaking it and listening to their playerbase. So don't hestiate to pick it up if you are into this kind of genre, as I've had a pretty fun time and do not regret the small purchase price at all. Here's to hoping they continue to flesh it out.

review:
Mall Empire - экономическая стратегия от Games++ на движке Unity, в которой вы должны построить торговый центр, таким образом комбинируя его составляющие, чтобы получать максимальную прибыль.

Я думаю почти все игроки 20+ в детстве играли в градостроительные симуляторы типа SimCity и Utopia, мы даже строили и развивали конкретные дома и магазины, но вот торговые центры не припомню.

Смысл игры, как я описывал ранее, достаточно прост и ясен: развить свой торговый центр "Империя". Сложность заключается в том, что для наибольшего дохода, вы должны подключить свое логическое мышление, и скомбинировать составляющие центра таким образом, чтобы они были максимально привлекательны для покупателей. Чем больше покупателей тем больше "сердечек" (одна из двух внутри-игровых валют), за которые вы можете приобретать еще больше магазинов, кафе, ресторанов и т.п.

Перейдем к процессу. Итак, вас встречает простое меню, из 3‐х основных компонентов: новая игра, продолжить, выход. В правом верхнем углу вам предоставлена возможность выключить музыкальное сопровождение, а в левом посетить соц. страницы создателей. Начинаем игру. Вам дан 1 этаж вашей будущей империи, 100 сердечек и 500 тыс. долларов. Можно застраиваться, но не стоит торопиться. Сначала осмотримся. Открываем меню "Строить", именно здесь вы можете просматривать все возможные компоненты будущего торгового центра (в том числе основные, такие как этаж, лифт, и одна секция). Так как мы собираемся развиваться далее одного этажа, в первую очередь построим лифты, а после уже начнем заполнять магазинами. Если что-то пошло не так, рядом с меню "Строить", есть значок-экскаватор, который снесет любую постройку. В меню "Управление" вы можете покупать всевозможную рекламу и новые магазины.  А так же есть еще уйма дополнительных возможностей, вроде улучшения магазинов (увеличение количества товара в нем) и экспресс кредита.
Все, готово! Теперь успевай собирать прибыль и застраивать новые этажи!

Графика в духе старых игр, простая и приятная. Музыкальное сопровождение ненавязчивое и спокойное, даже чрезмерно. Пару минут прослушивания, и мои глаза начинали слипаться, поэтому я был вынужден "мутить" ее, и включать что-нибудь подвижное, что соответствует игровому процессу.

Mall Empire - отличный симулятор, качественный продукт, соответствует заявленному описанию. Прекрасно расслабляет и в то же время развлекает. Подойдет для ненавязчивого и приятного времяпровождения.
Единственное что хотелось бы увидеть в дальнейшем - русскую локализацию, возможно большее количество магазинов, их оживления в виде анимации или еще чего-то, а так же разнообразие музыкальных тем.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005879531', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1488152231}
review:
I've only played it a little while so far, but I plan to play it a bit at a later date.  

My first impression is that this is just like Mall Developer Story for mobiles.  If you liked that, you'll like this.  Roughly the same price too.  Had this game been a higher price tag I wouldn't be able to recommend it.  Being $3.99 regularly it's not that big of a risk.

Something that I don't like is how you collect money.  A little coin appears on the stores.  You have a window where you can click it to collect your money.  Miss it?  You miss the money.  Seems really weird in this kind of game to have that mechanic.  If I never play the game again, it's probably because of that.  Takes away from building the mall and forces you to go clicking everywhere to get cash.

Sort of a side note.  People that make games like this obviously have zero clue how a mall is actually run.  To put it simply, malls are like rental properties.  The management team are landlords.  Each space is rented out to a tenant.  The mall builds the property, keeps it maintained, and tries to entice businesses to move in and open stores.  I would really like to see someone make a mall management game like that some day.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075426581', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1487374387}
review:
Mall Empire - это симулятор ТЦ в стиле Tycoon. В вашем распоряжении огромный торговый центр, и вам предстоит обустроить его помещениями под потребности посетителей. Вы должны расппланировать, где и как  разместить залы, включающей в себя рестораны, зоны отдыха, магазины и лифты и сделать это так, что бы это было удобно посетителям и не очень затратно вам по деньгам. 
В игре есть 2 вида валют - обычные деньги и сердечки, Сердца - это то на сколько довольны посетители вашего ТЦ, чем довольнее покупатель тем больше сердечек, а как получать деньги объяснять думаю не стоит.


Плюсы:


Большой выбор магазинов - более 50.

Большой выбор  персонажей - более 20.

Множество комбинаций обустраивания своего ТЦ.

Timeclicker.


Минусы:


Язык в игре - только английский (хотелось бы и русский).

На данный момент это отсутствие ачивок(которые должны добавить в скорем времени).

Баг с монетами над отделами, иногда просто исчезают. 

Персонажи почти без эмоций.

Но так как эта игра первая у разработчиков, думаю, они еще все наверстают и исправят минусы :)
В итоге напишу, что игра стоит своих денег, при том, что с карточек вы отобьете чуть ли не пол стоимости самой игры(на данный момент).
Поэтому дам ей оценку 7\10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198154026559', 'num_games_owned': 1753, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1487436031}
review:
Mall Empire - конструктор торгового центра, сделанный на движке юнити. Смысл игры - строить новые магазины, с целью получения прибыли, которая понадобится для дальнейшего развития торгового центра. В игре есть 2 вида валюты: 1-я деньги, необходимые для строительства новых магазинов, 2-я сердца, на которые можно приобретать "чертежи" новых магазинов.
Из плюсов можно отметить:
+ музыкальное сопровождение (оно не надоедает со временем)
+ огромный выбор магазинов
+ вариативное размещение магазинов.
Лично для меня в этой игре есть всего 2 несущественных минуса: 
1-й отсутствие русского языка 
2-й отсутствие ачивок.
Если вам нравятся строительные симуляторы, то эта игра должна вас заинтересовать.

review:
Mall Empire - простенький конструктор торгового центра сделанный на движке юните. Концепция позаимствована у многих других похожих игр жанра, наподобие симсити. Весь смысл -строиться, привлекать покупателей, получать с них бабосы и прочие плюшки, изучать новые чертежи и дальше строиться. И так до бесконечности. Игра без ачивок, что делает ее немного скучнее, ведь в принципе - тут особо не к чему стремиться. Оформление тоже простенькое, карточки хоть и прописаны в описании игры - но пока не падают. Также имеется довольно приличное количество несущественных багов. Язык в игре - только английский. Игра откровенно говоря на любителя, да и ставить заплатки надо на нее еще неоднократно. Однако согласно описанию,это первая игра разработчиков и они готовы воплотить в игре и задумки игроков. Так что играйте, предлагайте свои идеи, возможно именно вам удастся сделать проект чуть более веселым и подходящим для более широкой аудитории геймеров.
На данный момент цена кажется довольно сильно завышенной.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032088203', 'num_games_owned': 828, 'num_reviews': 142, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1487188500}
review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vp-H0xc7D4E

I’m going to give this a positive review because the price is slated to be “less than four dollars” according to the developer.

Mall Empire is the developer’s first game and it shows. While the game is by no means unplayable it doesn’t have much in the way of strategy or management that I was personally looking for in a mall tycoon style game.

I would liken the game more towards the clicker genre rather than tycoon or management simulators. 

The game involves you placing a variety of different shops and rooms in your mall, gaining money by clicking on each individual shop when a small icon pops up, then using that money to buy more shops.

That’s pretty much the extent of the game. You can do a few more tasks such as buying advertising to increase the amount of people that visit, but this doesn’t seem to be needed.

Within the first 20 minutes I was able to keep accumulating more and more money to the point where it didn’t seem like there was much of a challenge involved.

By the time I got to even the second story of my mall, the game became very difficult to manage in that I had to constantly look and click on every shop each minute to claim my money from it. The money you gain from shops is on a timer, so if you miss that timer you simply don’t get the money from the shop.

The help system and tutorial for the game gives you the bare minimum information needed to understand what to do. There is a lack of tooltips when you hover over anything, so you don’t necessarily know what everything does.

There are a few minor, but not game-breaking glitches in the game that include blueprints for stores that I have already bought still showing up in menus and some other similar things.

The developer is obviously foreign, so sentences and grammar are often in broken english. I would highly recommend they have someone who uses english as a first language to go over and redo the writing throughout the game.

All that being said, the price being so low combined with the game being simple, but playable mean that I can still say that if you are looking for a very basic mall creation or clicker game to spend a bit of time on while you do other things, you may find some enjoyment out of it.

I also hope that my video and written review will help the developer update the game to fix issues and include more features for either this or their future projects.
